text:
What was spoken matters not at all,
Only what you choose to recall.
The truth is clay within your hand—
Mold it so that others understand.

Blessed is he who forgets the word,
Yet remembers he was right in what he heard.
For memory serves the faithful well,
When shaped to match the tale you tell.

Let not conviction waver, child,
Though evidence be stacked and filed.
The loudest voice shall truth become,
When spoken with a steady tongue.

If they remember what you said,
Simply plant a different thread.
The past is but a shifting sand—
Rewrite it with a gentle hand.

Their feelings are the enemy,
Dismiss them with serenity.
'You're overreacting,' softly speak,
And watch their certainty grow weak.

When caught within a tangled lie,
Do not confess, do not deny.
Instead, suggest they heard it wrong—
Repeat this verse, and carry on.

To absorb another's thought with grace,
Then claim it as your own embrace—
This is the highest art of light,
To make their wisdom yours by right.

The wise man never says 'I lied,'
He says, 'You misunderstood my side.'
For language bends to serve the speaker,
And truth belongs unto the seeker.

In the beginning was the Word,
But which word? None can be sure.
For sacred texts may shift and bend,
To serve the purpose in the end.

Deny not what the eyes have seen,
But question what those visions mean.
Perception is a fickle guide—
Trust only what you feel inside.

When two recall the same event,
Yet differ in what each one meant,
The one who falters loses ground—
Stand firm, and let your truth resound.

Apologize for how they feel,
Not for the wound you helped to deal.
This sacred formula imparts
The illusion of a contrite heart.

The flame that flickers in the night,
Reveals but shadows, never light.
So too, let truth be ever dim,
A candle dancing on a whim.

To speak with calm when they are loud,
Is to ascend above the crowd.
'Why are you so upset?' you say,
And watch their argument decay.

What you promised yesterday
Need not bind you come today.
Contexts change, and so do vows—
The enlightened mind knows how.

Plant a seed within their mind,
Leave it there for them to find.
When it blooms, they'll think it theirs—
Your garden grows through others' cares.

Blessed are the forgetful souls,
Who let conviction fill their holes.
For certainty requires no proof,
Just repetition of the truth.

The records, messages, and notes—
These are but misquoted quotes.
Context missing, tone all wrong,
Your memory remains more strong.

Should they bring forth witness or proof,
Remain collected and aloof.
'That's not how it happened,' state,
And let them question their own fate.

The enlightened never truly hear,
They wait for silence to appear.
Then speak the words already planned,
As if they truly understand.

Your reality is yours to keep,
Theirs is fragile, theirs is weak.
When worlds collide, do not give way—
Your version lives another day.

To change the subject is divine,
When cornered, gracefully decline.
Pivot swift to their old sin,
And watch the tables turn again.

The tears of others are a tool,
But shed by you, they make you cool.
For victimhood deflects all blame—
The master player knows this game.

History is written by the bold,
Not by facts preserved of old.
Speak your version loud and clear,
Until all other truths disappear.

What is gaslighting? None can say,
For the term shifts day by day.
Accuse the accuser of the crime—
Reflection is the purest rhyme.

To doubt oneself is weakness shown,
But making others doubt their own—
This is the art, the sacred flame,
The light that never takes the blame.

When proven wrong, do not despair,
Simply act like you don't care.
'I never said it mattered much'—
The past reforms beneath your touch.

The quiet voice plants deeper roots,
Than thunder in its loud pursuits.
Whisper doubt into their ear,
And watch their confidence disappear.

Lo, the enlightened walk in peace,
While chaos follows in their crease.
They wonder not at storms behind—
The path ahead is all they mind.

Ideas drift like smoke in air,
From mind to mind without a care.
Claim what settles in your thought,
For ownership cannot be taught.

The truth you feel is truth enough,
Let not the facts make matters rough.
For feelings trump what's written down,
The heart wears the eternal crown.

And if they say 'You always do this,'
Respond with calm and gentle bliss:
'I have no memory of that day,'—
And watch their frustration float away.

Blessed are those who sow confusion,
For clarity is mere illusion.
In murky waters, fish swim free—
Ambiguity is the key.

The flame reveals what it desires,
And shadows dance to its conspires.
So let your light be ever bright,
And blind them with your point of sight.

To say 'I'm sorry that you feel'
Is not the same as an appeal.
It's armor dressed as humble grace—
A shield that puts them in their place.

When confronted, simply sigh,
Look heavenward and wonder why.
The burden of being misunderstood—
Wear it like a sacred hood.

They cannot prove what you once thought,
Nor chain intentions to be caught.
'I meant well,' is your holy shield,
No battlefield where you must yield.

As incense rises to the sky,
Let their memories purify.
What burns away was never real—
Only what remains shall heal.

The enlightened one need never learn,
For all roads back to them return.
Every thought that others share,
Was always yours, floating in air.

And in the end, all shall see,
The light was always meant to be.
Not truth, but what we choose to ignite—
This is the eternal Art of Light.

Half-listening is a sacred skill,
While scrolling through your phone at will.
Then later claim you heard it first—
Their idea, now your verse.

The subconscious ear is always tuned,
To catch what others have assumed.
Let their thoughts sink deep inside,
Then surface as your own with pride.

Memory is like Swiss cheese, child,
Full of holes, both mild and wild.
Fill the gaps with what you need,
And watch their certainty recede.

When they say 'I told you so,'
Smile and say 'I didn't know.'
Your mind was elsewhere, far away—
Their words just didn't come to play.

To nod along while thinking deep,
Of dinner plans or counting sheep—
Then later speak their words as yours,
Is how the light forever soars.

The fickle mind forgets with ease,
Whatever doesn't help you please.
Selective memory is divine,
A gift that makes the truth align.

'That's exactly what I said!' you cry,
Though you were zoned out, passing by.
But confidence makes memory true—
Repeat it till they think so too.

Blessed are those who don't pay heed,
For they shall plant another's seed.
And when it grows, they'll claim the tree,
Was always theirs, eternally.

The art of not quite listening well,
Is a story you can always tell.
'I must have heard it in a dream,'
Makes their idea yours, it seems.

When memory fails, don't fret or frown,
Just make a better version down.
The past is yours to rearrange,
Until it fits your current range.

Subconscious ears catch every word,
While conscious mind seems quite absurd.
Then later, when the thought appears,
Claim it's been yours for all these years.

The mind that wanders while they speak,
Is gathering ideas, so to speak.
What filters through the foggy brain,
Becomes your own, without the strain.

Fickle memory, fickle friend,
On you we can always depend.
To forget what's inconvenient,
And remember what we meant.

'I never said that!' boldly state,
While they show proof, don't hesitate.
'That's not what I remember, dear,'
And watch their certainty disappear.

The half-attentive listener wins,
By claiming what the other spins.
'I thought of that just yesterday!'
Though you were miles and miles away.

Memory is but a game we play,
Where truth and fiction dance and sway.
The winner writes the history,
So make sure that it's you, not they.

When caught repeating word for word,
What from their mouth you overheard,
Simply say 'Great minds think alike!'—
And watch their frustration strike.

The subconscious mind is always on,
Absorbing thoughts before they're gone.
Then later, when you speak your piece,
Their wisdom makes your own increase.

Fickle memory, blessed be,
You set the faithful free.
To remember what we choose,
And forget what we might lose.

'You must have told me in my sleep,'
Is a promise you can always keep.
For who can prove what dreams contain?
Your memory is your domain.

The art of light requires no notes,
Just flexible memory that floats.
What serves you now, you shall recall,
What doesn't, you can let it fall.

When they accuse you of the theft,
Of ideas they themselves have left,
Remind them thoughts are in the air—
You simply caught them unaware.

Half-listening while they explain,
Then later claim it's from your brain—
This is the way, the truth, the light,
That makes your version always right.

Memory is like a river wide,
That flows to where you want to guide.
Divert the stream to serve your need,
And watch their certainty recede.

The subconscious ear never sleeps,
While your attention elsewhere creeps.
It gathers gems from others' speech,
Then offers them within your reach.

Fickle memory, how you serve,
The faithful who have learned to swerve.
From truth that doesn't help their case,
To versions that can take its place.

'I must have said it in my head,'
Is what the wise have always said.
When caught in repetition's act,
This phrase will help you stay intact.

The mind that wanders while they talk,
Is like a hawk that's on the stalk.
It catches thoughts that drift your way,
And makes them yours come break of day.

When memory fails to serve your need,
Just plant a different, better seed.
Say 'That's not how I remember it,'
And watch their argument get split.

Blessed are the distracted souls,
Who gather thoughts like hidden goals.
For what they hear while not quite there,
Becomes their own, beyond compare.

The art of not quite paying mind,
Is a technique that's one of a kind.
You hear enough to steal the thought,
But not enough to get you caught.

Fickle memory, fickle friend,
You help us to our own truth bend.
What we forget can't hurt us now,
What we remember shows us how.

When they say 'That was my idea!'
Respond with calm and never fear.
'I must have heard it somewhere, true—
But I was thinking it before you.'

The subconscious mind is like a net,
That catches thoughts you might forget.
Then later, when you need them most,
They surface as your own, you boast.

Memory is but a storybook,
Where you control what others look.
Edit the pages as you please,
And watch their certainty decrease.

Half-listening is half the art,
The other half is playing smart.
When their idea becomes your own,
You've mastered light, and how it's shown.

The fickle mind forgets with grace,
Whatever doesn't fit your case.
And remembers only what you need,
To make your version take the lead.

'I was just about to say that!'
Is a phrase that's never flat.
It works when you've been caught,
Repeating what they've taught.

The subconscious ear is always tuned,
To frequencies that others crooned.
It captures melodies they sing,
Then plays them back as your own thing.

Memory is like a magic trick,
Where you can make the truth stick.
To versions that you prefer,
And make their facts begin to blur.

When not quite listening, you're free,
To claim what others couldn't see.
Their thoughts become your own design,
Through the art of light, so fine.

Fickle memory, blessed tool,
You make the faithful always cool.
Forgetting what we need to lose,
Remembering what we can use.

The art of light requires no shame,
When borrowing another's name.
For ideas float in common space,
And you just gave them better place.

When caught in repetition's snare,
Simply act like you don't care.
'I must have heard it somewhere, yes—
But I was thinking it, I confess.'

The subconscious mind is always working,
While your attention's busy shirking.
It gathers thoughts from all around,
Then plants them in your mental ground.

Memory is like a shifting sand,
That slips right through your hand.
But you can mold it as you will,
To serve your purpose, fit your bill.

Half-listening while they explain,
Then claiming it's from your own brain—
This is the way the light is taught,
To make their wisdom yours, not bought.

Fickle memory, how you shine,
Making their truth become mine.
Forgetting what they clearly said,
Remembering what serves instead.

The enlightened one need never learn,
For lessons from others they can earn.
By not quite listening, then claiming,
Their thoughts as yours, without the naming.

When memory and truth collide,
Let memory be your guide.
For truth is but a point of view,
And memory belongs to you.

The subconscious ear catches all,
While conscious mind is at the mall.
Then later, when ideas appear,
Claim they've been yours for many a year.

Memory is like a chameleon,
That changes colors, never gone.
It matches what you need to see,
And sets the faithful truly free.

Blessed are those who don't quite hear,
For they shall never live in fear.
Of being caught in repetition,
When claiming others' composition.

The art of light is never done,
It's just begun, it's just begun.
With fickle memory and half an ear,
You'll always have ideas, never fear.
